ai-pli-tv-kd15:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:1.1.2_0: At that time the monks from the group of six rubbed their bodies—thighs, arms, chest, and back—against trees while bathing.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:1.1.4_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this? They are just like boxers and city slickers who beautify their bodies.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:1.1.16_0: “You should not rub your body against a tree while bathing.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.2.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six grew their hair long.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.2.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,

ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.3.8_0: or smooth your hair with water and oil.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.3.9_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.4.7_0: Soon afterwards a certain monk had a sore on his face.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.1_0: On one occasion in Rājagaha there was a hilltop fair,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.2_0: and the monks from the group of six went to see it.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.3_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.4_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics go to see dancing, singing, and the playing of music? They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.5_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.6_0: “You should not go to see dancing, singing, and the playing of music.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:2.6.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six recited the Teaching by singing in a drawn-out fashion.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.3_0: “These Sakyan ascetics sing just like we do.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.4_0: The monks heard those people complaining,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.5_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.6_0: “How can the monks from the group of six sing like this?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.10_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.11_0: “There are these five dangers in reciting the Teaching by singing in a drawn-out fashion:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.12_0: one delights in the sound; others delight in the sound; householders criticize it; for one who takes pleasure in the melody, the concentration is disrupted; later generations follow one’s example.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.13_0: These are the five drawbacks in reciting with a drawn-out singing sound.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.14_0: You should not recite the Teaching by singing in a drawn-out fashion.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.1.15_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.2.1_0: At this time the monks were afraid of wrongdoing and did not remember.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:3.2.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,

ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.3_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.5_0: “You should not wear a fleecy woolen robe with the fleece on the outside.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:4.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.1_0: On one occasion when the mango trees in King Bimbisāra’s park were bearing fruit,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.3_0: to eat as many mangoes as they wished.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.4_0: The monks from the group of six plucked and ate them all, even the young ones.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.5_0: Just then the King needed mangoes.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.7_0: “Go to the park and bring back mangoes.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.8_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” they went to the park and said to the park keeper,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.9_0: “The King needs mangoes. Please get some.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.11_0: The monks plucked and ate them all, including the young ones.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.12_0: They reported to the King what had happened. He said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.13_0: “It’s good that the venerables have eaten the mangoes. Still, the Buddha has praised moderation.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.14_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.15_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics eat the King’s mangoes without moderation?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.16_0: The monks heard those people complaining,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.1.19_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.1_0: Soon afterwards an association in the Sangha was offering a meal to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.3_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept it.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.6_0: Soon afterwards an association in the Sangha was offering a meal to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.7_0: They were unable to make mango pieces and so they gave whole mangoes in the dining hall.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.8_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept them.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.10_0: I allow you to eat fruit that is allowable for ascetics for any of five reasons:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.11_0: it has been damaged by fire, it has been damaged by a knife, it has been damaged by a nail, it’s seedless, the seeds have been removed.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:5.2.12_0: I allow you to eat fruit that is allowable for ascetics for any of these five reasons.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.1_0: On one occasion a monk had been bitten by a snake and died.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.3_0: “That monk had not radiated good will to the four royal snake clans.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.4_0: Had he done so, he would not have died.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.6_0: The Virūpakkhas, the Erāpathas, the Chabyāputtas, and the Kaṇhāgotamas.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.7_0: That monk had not radiated good will to the four royal snake clans.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.8_0: Had he done so, he would not have died.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.9_0: To protect yourselves, monks, you should spread good will to these four royal snake clans.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.10_0: And it should be done like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.11_0: I have good will toward the Virūpakkhas,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.19_0: May the footless not harm me!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.20_0: May the two-legged not hurt me.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.21_0: May the four-legged not hurt me,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.22_0: May the many-legged not hurt me.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.23_0: All sentient beings, all living things,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.25_0: may they see only nice things,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.26_0: May none meet with anything bad.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.35_0: I pay homage to the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:6.1.36_0: And to the seven fully awakened Buddhas.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.1_0: On one occasion a monk who was tormented by lust cut off his own penis.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.3_0: “This fool has cut off one thing, when he should have cut off something else.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.4_0: You should not cut off your own penis.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:7.1.5_0: If you do, you commit a serious offense.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.1_0: On one occasion a prominent merchant of Rājagaha had obtained a very valuable block of sandalwood.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.3_0: “I will have a bowl carved from this block of sandal.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.4_0: I’ll use the chips myself, but give the bowl away as a gift.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.5_0: He then had a bowl carved, put it in a carrying net, hung it at the end of a succession of vertical bamboo poles, and announced,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.6_0: “I will give this bowl to any perfected ascetic or brahmin who brings it down by supernormal powers.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.7_0: Pūraṇa Kassapa went to that merchant and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.8_0: “I’m perfected and have supernormal powers. Give me the bowl.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.9_0: “If you’re perfected and have supernormal powers, then bring it down and it’s yours.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.15_0: “I’m perfected and have supernormal powers. Give me the bowl.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.16_0: “If you’re perfected and have supernormal powers, then bring it down and it’s yours.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.17_0: Soon afterwards, after robing up in the morning, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna and Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja took their bowls and robes and entered Rājagaha for alms.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.19_0: “Venerable, you are perfected and have supernormal powers.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.20_0: If you go and bring down that bowl,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.22_0: “Venerable, you too are perfected and have supernormal powers.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.25_0: Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja then rose up in the air, took hold of that bowl, and circled around Rājagaha three times.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.26_0: Just then that merchant together with his wives and children was standing in his own house with joined palms raised in homage, thinking,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.27_0: “May Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja land right here at our house.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.28_0: And Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja did just that.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.29_0: The merchant then took the bowl from his hands, filled it with expensive non-staple food, and gave it back to Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.1.30_0: who then left for the monastery.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.2_0: that Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja had taken down the merchant’s bowl,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.3_0: and making a great uproar, they followed right behind him.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.4_0: The Buddha heard the loud sound of recitation.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.5_0: the Buddha asked Venerable Ānanda what it was,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.6_0: “Ānanda, why is there this loud sound of crows?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.7_0: and Ānanda explained to him all that had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.9_0: that Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja had taken down the merchant’s bowl,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.10_0: and those people followed behind him.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.12_0: The Buddha then had the Sangha of monks gathered and questioned Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.13_0: “Is it true, Bhāradvāja, that you brought down that merchant’s bowl?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.16_0: “It’s not suitable, Bhāradvāja, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.17_0: How can you show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders for the sake of a miserable wooden bowl?
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.18_0: It’s just like a woman showing her private parts for a miserable _māsaka_ coin.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.19_0: In the same way, you show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders for the sake of a miserable wooden bowl.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.20_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.22_0: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.23_0: “You should not show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.24_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.25_0: Now destroy that wooden bowl and make it into splinters. Give these to the monks to use as scent in ointment.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.26_0: And you should not use a wooden bowl.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:8.2.27_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.1_0: After robing up the following morning, Venerable Ānanda took his bowl and robe, went to the house of Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, and told him,

ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.10_0: Soon afterwards Vaḍḍha, together with his wives and children, together with his friends and relatives, with wet clothes and wet hair, went to the Buddha. He bowed down at the Buddha’s feet and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.11_0: “Sir, I’ve committed an offense. Foolishly, deludedly, and unskillfully I acted like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.12_0: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.13_0: “Certainly you have committed an offense. Foolishly, deludedly, and unskillfully you acted like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.14_0: But since you acknowledge your offense and you make amends for it in accordance with the Teaching, I accept your confession.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.5.15_0: For this is called growth in the training of the noble ones, that is, acknowledging an offense, making amends in accordance with the Teaching, and undertaking restraint for the future.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.1_0: When the message had been delivered, the Buddha said to the monks,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.2_0: “Well then, the Sangha should turn the almsbowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.3_0: When a lay follower has eight qualities, you should turn your bowl upright for him:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.4_0: he is not trying to stop monks from acquiring material gains; he is not trying to harm monks; he is not trying to get monks to lose their place of residence; he doesn’t abuse or revile monks; he doesn’t cause division between monks; he doesn’t disparage the Buddha; he doesn’t disparage the Teaching; he doesn’t disparage the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.6.5_0: You should turn your bowl upright for a lay follower on these eight grounds.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.1_0: And the turning of the bowl upright is to be done like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.2_0: Vaḍḍha the Licchavī should approach the Sangha, put his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.3_0: ‘Venerables, the Sangha has overturned the bowl against me. I’m prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.’
ai-pli-tv-kd15:20.7.4_0: I’m conducting myself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released. I ask the Sangha to turn the bowl upright for me.’

ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.1_0: When the Buddha had stayed at Vesālī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward the country of Bhaggā.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.3_0: he stayed at Susumāragira in the Bhesakaḷā Grove, the deer park.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.4_0: At this time Prince Bodhi had recently built the Kokanada stilt house. It had not yet been inhabited by any ascetic or brahmin, or anyone else.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.5_0: The Prince said to the young brahmin Sañcikāputta,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.6_0: “My dear Sañcikāputta, please go to the Buddha, bow down in my name with your head at his feet,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.7_0: He is rarely ill or unwell. His strength, energy, and vigor.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.8_0: if he is healthy, strong, and living at ease.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.10_0: might accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.11_0: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” Sañcikāputta went to the Buddha and exchanged pleasantries with him. He then sat down
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.12_0: and told the Buddha all he had been asked to say,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.13_0: “The Prince is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.15_0: concluding with the invitation for the meal on the following day.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.1.16_0: And the Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.1_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Sañcikāputta got up from his seat, returned to the Prince, and told him what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.2_0: “I gave the ascetic Gotama your message,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.3_0: if he is healthy, strong, and living at ease.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.5_0: together with the mendicant Saṅgha, might please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.’
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.7_0: The next morning Prince Bodhi had various kinds of fine food prepared, and had the entire Kokanada stilt house covered with white cloth, all the way to the bottom step of the staircase. He then said to Sañcikāputta,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.9_0: and tell him the meal is ready.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.12_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Prince Bodhi’s home.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.13_0: The Prince was standing outside the gateway, waiting for the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.14_0: Seeing the Buddha coming off in the distance,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.15_0: he went out to meet him, bowed down to him, and went to the Kokanada stilt house with the Buddha in front.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.16_0: But the Buddha stopped at the bottom stair of that staircase.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.18_0: “Sir, please step on the cloth. It will be for my longterm benefit and happiness.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.21_0: When the Prince made his request for the third time,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.22_0: “Sir, please step on the cloth. It will be for my longterm benefit and happiness.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.23_0: Then the Buddha glanced at Venerable Ānanda.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.24_0: And Ānanda said to the Prince,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.2.26_0: The Buddha doesn’t step on cloth coverings. The Buddha has compassion for later generations.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.1_0: The Prince then had the cloth folded up and had a seat prepared up in the stilt house.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.2_0: Then the Buddha ascended the longhouse and sat on the seats spread out together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.3_0: The Prince personally served the various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, the Prince sat down to one side.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.4_0: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.5_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.6_0: “You should not step on a cloth covering.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.3.7_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.1_0: On one occasion a woman who was unable to conceive invited the monks, prepared a cloth, and said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.3_0: But being afraid of wrongdoing, they refused.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.4_0: “Please step on the cloth as a blessing.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.5_0: But being afraid of wrongdoing, they refused.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.6_0: That woman complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.7_0: “How can the venerables, when asked, not step on a cloth as a blessing?”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.8_0: The monks heard the complaints of that woman
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.11_0: I allow you, when asked, to step on a cloth covering as a blessing for householders.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.12_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not step on a sheet after washing their feet.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.13_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.14_0: “I allow you to step on a sheet after washing your feet.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:21.4.15_0: The second recitation section is finished.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.6_0: they saw the group of six monks with their sunshades.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.7_0: They said to that lay follower,

ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.9_0: “These are not monks; they are wanderers.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:23.2.10_0: And they made a bet on whether they were monks or not.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.26_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.27_0: “I allow you to give a sick monk permission to use a staff and a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.28_0: And the designation should be given like this.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.29_0: After approaching the Sangha, that monk should put his upper robe over one shoulder and pay respect at the feet of the senior monks. He should then squat on his heels, put raise his joined palms, and say,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.31_0: I’m unable to walk about without a staff
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.32_0: I’m unable to carry my bowl around without a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.33_0: I ask the Sangha to give me permission to use a staff and a carrying-net.’
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.34_0: And they should ask a second
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.35_0: And they should ask a third time.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.36_0: a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.37_0: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.38_0: Monk so-and-so is sick. He is unable to walk about without a staff or to carry his bowl around without a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.39_0: He is asking the Sangha to give me permission to use a staff and a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.40_0: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should give him permission to use a staff and a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.42_0: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.43_0: Monk so-and-so is sick. He is unable to walk about without a staff or to carry his bowl around without a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.44_0: He is asking the Sangha to give me permission to use a staff and a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.45_0: The Sangha gives him permission to use a staff and a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.46_0: Any monk who approves of giving monk so-and-so permission to use a staff and a carrying-net should remain silent.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.47_0: Any monk who doesn’t approves should speak up.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.48_0: The Sangha has given monk so-and-so permission to use a staff and a carrying-net.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:24.3.49_0: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.1_0: At that time there was a monk who was a regurgitator.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.3_0: But the monks complained and criticized him,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.4_0: “This monk is eating at the wrong time.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.5_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.6_0: “This monk has only recently passed away as a cow.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.7_0: I allow a regurgitator to regurgitate.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.8_0: But you should not take it out of the mouth and then swallow it.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:25.1.9_0: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:26.1.1_0: Soon afterwards an association in the Sangha was offering a meal to the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:26.1.2_0: Lots of rice fell on the floor in the dining hall.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:26.1.3_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:26.1.4_0: “When they are given rice, how can the Sakyan ascetics not receive it with care? Each lump of rice is the result of a lot of work.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:26.1.5_0: The monks heard those people complaining,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:26.1.7_0: “I allow you to pick up yourselves what falls down when given, and then eat it.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:26.1.8_0: It has been relinquished by the donors.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.2.1_0: Soon afterwards the monks were cutting their nails with their nails, with their teeth, or by grinding them on a wall.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.2.8_0: At this time the monks from the group of six polished their finger and toe nails.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.2.14_0: But I allow you to remove dirt.”

ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.5.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six had cut their hair with scisors.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.5.7_0: A monk who had a sore on his head was unable to shave with a razor.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.1_0: On one occasion a monk’s ear was blocked by earwax.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.4_0: Soon the monks from the group of six used luxurious ear-picks made of gold and silver.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.5_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.6_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.7_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.8_0: “You should not use a luxurious ear-pick.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.9_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:27.6.10_0: I allow a knife handle made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, and shell.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.1.1_0: At one time the monks from the group of six had amassed a large number of metal and bronze goods.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.1.2_0: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.1.3_0: “How can the Sakyan ascetics amass a large number of metal and bronze goods? They are just like merchants.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.1.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.1.5_0: “You should not amass a large number of metal and bronze goods.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.1_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept ointment boxes, ointment sticks, earpicks, or even metal used for joining.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.3_0: “I allow an ointment box, an ointment stick, an ear-pick, and metal used for joining.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.4_0: On one occasion the monks from the group of six were sitting using their upper robes as a back-and-knee strap.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.5_0: The panels of the robes broke up.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.6_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.7_0: “You should not sit using your upper robe as a back-and-knee strap.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.9_0: On one occasion a certain monk who was sick

ai-pli-tv-kd15:28.2.16_0: “I allow a warp, a reed, a weft, a shuttle, and all weaving equipment.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.1.1_0: On one occasion a monk entered a village for alms without a belt.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.1.5_0: After being released, that monk went to the monastery and told the monks what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.1.7_0: “You should not enter a village without a belt.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.1.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.2_0: belts with multiple strings, belts like the head of a water snake, belts of twisted strings of various colors, belts like ornamental strings.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.3_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.4_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.5_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.6_0: “You should not wear a luxurious belt.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.7_0: belts with multiple strings, belts like the head of a water snake, belts of twisted strings of various colors, belts like ornamental strings.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.8_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.9_0: I allow two kinds of belt:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.10_0: made from strips of cloth and made from pigs’ intestines.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.11_0: The edges of the belts wore away.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.12_0: “I allow a belt of twisted strings of various colors and a belt like ornamental strings.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.13_0: The ends of the belts wore away.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.14_0: “I allow looping the end and then sewing around the loop, and sewing into a knot.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.15_0: The loop at the end wore away.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.17_0: Soon the monks from the group of six wore luxurious buckles made of gold and silver.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.18_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.19_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.20_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,

ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.2.23_0: I allow nose droppers made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.1_0: On one occasion Venerable Ānanda robed up in light upper robes and entered a village for alms.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.2_0: A whirlwind lifted up his robes.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.3_0: When he had returned to the monastery, he told the monks what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.6_0: Soon the monks from the group of six wore luxurious toggles made of gold and silver.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.7_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.8_0: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.9_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.11_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.12_0: I allow toggles made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, shell, and string.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.13_0: The monks fastened toggles and loops to their robes,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.14_0: but it caused the robes to wear.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.16_0: “I allow toggles made of legs and strings.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.3.17_0: They fastened the toggle-shield and the loop-shield on the edge of the robe.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.4.9_0: The monks from the group of six wore their upper robes like householders.

ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.5.1_0: The monks from the group of six wore their sarongs like loin cloths.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.5.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,

ai-pli-tv-kd15:29.5.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:30.1.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six used carrying poles with loads on both ends.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:30.1.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:30.1.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:30.1.5_0: “You should not use a carrying pole with loads on both ends.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:30.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:30.1.7_0: I allow a carrying pole with a load on one end, a two-person carrying pole with a load in the middle, loads for the head, loads for the shoulder, loads for the hip, and hanging loads.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.1_0: At that time the monks did not use their teeth while eating.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.2_0: As a consequence they had bad breath.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.3_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.4_0: “There are these five disadvantages of not brushing your teeth:
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.5_0: it’s bad for your eyes; you get bad breath; your ability to taste is reduced; bile and phlegm cover over the food; you don’t enjoy the food.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.6_0: These are the five drawbacks of not using chew sticks.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.7_0: There are these five benefits of using chew sticks.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.8_0: it’s good for your eyes; you don’t get bad breath; your ability to taste is improved; bile and phlegm don’t cover over the food; you enjoy the food.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.1.9_0: These are the five benefits of using chew sticks.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.1_0: The monks from the group of six used long toothbrushes and even used them to hit the novice monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.2_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.4_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.5_0: I allow toothbrushes that are a maximum of thirteen centimeters long. And you should not use them to hit the novice monks.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.7_0: On one occasion a monk used a toothbrush that was too short and it got stuck in his throat.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.8_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.9_0: “You should not use toothbrushes that are too short.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.10_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:31.2.11_0: You should not use toothbrushes shorter than seven centimeters.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.1_0: On one occasion the monks from the group of six set fire to a grove.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.4_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.5_0: “You should not set fire to groves.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.7_0: On one occasion the dwellings were overgrown with grass. When the forest was burning, the dwellings burnt too.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.8_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not light a counter-fire for protection.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.9_0: They told the Buddha what had happened, and he said,
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.1.10_0: “When the forest is burning, I allow you to light a counter-fire for protection.”
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.2.1_0: At that time the monks from the group of six ascended trees and then climbed from tree to tree.
ai-pli-tv-kd15:32.2.2_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
